Award.AwardTitle: A multivariate model of subadult age estimation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will explore the relationships among chronological age and dental formation, long bone growth and epiphyseal fusion in modern US children, using full body CT scans and sophisticated statistical models. A better understanding of these relationships is important not only for human biologists interested in childhood growth and life history patterns, but for bioarchaeologists and forensic anthropologists who want more accurate estimates of age at death in skeletal samples. NSF funds will support data collection and statistical consulting for the dental portion of the larger project. The project will result in freely accessible dental and skeletal data for a large, cross-sectional sample of modern children. An age estimation software program, and workshops to introduce the software, will also be developed and will be of interest across a range of research areas within and beyond anthropology.

Subadult age estimations are based on documented patterns of growth and development and are considered the most accurate estimation in the subadult biological profile. However, the major limitations of subadult age estimation are the lack of large, modern skeletal reference samples and the reliance on historical, primarily univariate methodological approaches. Most methods utilize a bone-by-bone or tooth-by-tooth approach and do not provide a means to incorporate markers from the entire subadult skeleton. In this project, the investigators will have access to de-identified medical examiner data. They will collect information on dental formation, epiphyseal fusion and long bone growth from multi-slice computed tomography (MSCT) and Lodox Statscan radiographic images for individuals between birth and 15 years (n = 1500), to develop a multivariate age estimation technique. Univariate and multivariate models will be compared in terms of accuracy, bias, and predictive ability, and the data will be incorporated into KidStats software with the goal of providing more accurate, precise, and unbiased age estimates for subadults. The freely accessible data will offer a range of research and collaborative opportunities for undergraduate and postgraduate students as well as researchers in anthropology and allied fields.

This project is jointly supported by NSF and the National Institute of Justice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological anthropologists use principles of growth and development to estimate age in a medicolegal setting, which is the sole contribution to the biological profile in subadults. Therefore, an accurate age estimation is crucial to facilitating a positive identification. The objective of this project was to collect dental formation, epiphyseal fusion and long bone data from computed tomography (CT) scans generated at medical examiner's offices to develop a multivariable age estimation technique. The working hypothesis was that the inclusion of dental and osteological age-informative data from a large, evenly distributed sample of diverse U.S. children will yield more accurate, precise, and unbiased age estimates for subadults than is currently available for application. All analyses from the current project supported the working hypothesis.

The current funding was dedicated to collecting dental development; the epiphyseal fusion and diaphyseal dimensions were also collected, but through another funding source. The CT scans were generated at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center, Office of the Medical Investigator (OMI) and the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Baltimore, Maryland. However, the dental data was solely collected on the OMI data and included individuals between birth and 20 years of age (n=1081) to ensure coverage of the entire growth and development period. Using CT images generated at MEOs provides a unique opportunity to overcome limitations associated with working on subadult material, such as collecting data on large, diverse samples of modern children, collecting all age indicators from the same specimens, and collecting all age indicators from the same images (i.e., both metric and ordinal data).

We used both multivariate adaptive regression splines and a mixed cumulative probit (MCP) to achieve the objectives; the MCP was developed as part of this funding. The MCP model is fully bayesian and uses both continuous and ordinal data to predict a continuous outcome (age). The model handles missing data, is built with cross validation, and incorporates variable correlations (i.e., does not violate assumptions of independence). Four algorithms for the MCP were developed: 1) uncorrelated data with homoscedasticity, 2) correlated data with homoscedasticity, 3) uncorrelated data with heteroscedasticity, and 4) correlated data with heteroscedasticity. Besides a point estimate and 95% confidence interval, information theory is part of the output. Not only is the algorithm incorporated into KidStats for the specific application in subadult age estimation, but it was also developed to be an R package. Therefore, the models will be freely available to any individual using similar data structures. 

We first demonstrated that multivariable, single indicator models yielded less biased, and more accurate and precise age estimates. The multivariable, single indicator models are defined as models that only contain variables from each indicator (i.e., dental development, diaphyseal lengths, or epiphyseal fusion stages), which contrasts multivariable, multi-indicator (i.e.,  multifactorial) models that combine variables from numerous indicators in one model. The improvement in multivariable, single indicator models was more apparent in epiphyseal fusion and dental development compared to diaphyseal dimensions and in older subadults (i.e., teenagers). The reduction of accuracy and increased bias with increased age was still present, but it was not nearly as extreme as the single variable models. There was also less fluctuation in the performance of the multivariable, single indicator models across the age range. The differential improvements of epiphyseal fusion and dental development multivariable models may be linked to differences in measurement precision between ordinal and continuous variables. The multivariable, multi-indicator approaches further improve model performance. Reduced bias and increased precision and accuracy were achieved in comparison to multivariable, single indicator models. Notably, the information theory demonstrated the varying importance of each variable and indictor depending on the age of the unknown. 

The results of the current funding expand our understanding of how information from all the variables and indicators can inform the subadult age estimation, as well as challenge the belief that one variable from one indicator could outperform a multitude of information from many variables and indicators. Ultimately, using multiple variables offers a more holistic reconstruction for age estimation and can provide a greater understanding of age indicators themselves. All data and images are available for further research.
